[[File:Aegaeon (2008 S1).jpg|thumb|Three images of the bright arc of the G Ring with Aegaeon embedded within it, taken over the course of ten minutes]] '''Aegaeon''' (pron-eniːˈdʒiːən respelleeJEEən, or as Greek ''Αιγαίων),'' also '''nowrapSaturn LIII''' (provisional designation '''nowrapS/2008 S 1'''), is a [[natural satellite]] of [[Saturn]]. Its discovery was announced by [[Carolyn Porco]] of the [[Cassini-Huygens|Cassini Imaging Science Team]] on March 3, 2009, from observations taken on August 15, 2008.ref[http://ciclops.org/view/5518/S2008_S_1?js=1 IAU Circular No. 9023]</ref>
Aegaeon orbits within the bright segment of Saturn's [[G Ring]], and is likely a major source of the ring.ref[http://ciclops.org/view/5474/Petite_Moon?js=1 Petite Moon], CICLOPS, 29 May 2009</ref> Debris knocked off the moon forms a bright arc near the inner edge, which in turn spreads to form the rest of the ring. Aegaeon orbits in a 7:6 [[orbital resonance|resonance]] with [[Mimas (moon)|Mimas]], which causes a ≈ 4-year oscillation of ≈ 4 km in its [[semi-major axis]]. Assuming it has the same [[albedo]] as [[Pallene (moon)|Pallene]], it is estimated to be half a kilometer in diameter. It orbits Saturn at an average distance of 167,500 km in 0.80812 days, at an [[inclination]] of 0.001° to Saturn's equator, with an [[eccentricity (orbit)|eccentricity]] of 0.0002.
It is named after [[Aegaeon]], one of the [[hecatonchires]].refJennifer Blue, [http://astrogeology.usgs.gov/HotTopics/index.php?/archives/362-Saturnian-Satellite-Named-Aegaeon.html Saturnian Satellite Named Aegaeon], USGS Astrogeology Hot Topics, 5 May 2009</ref>
